Hi,

I have tried spreadsheet example in several TDD courses and actually
i=
t didn't worked out so well. Spreadsheet application was a starting
point a=
nd then we moved into a complicated J2EE example.

The problem in this cour=
se setup is the amount of material
participants have to swallow and tolerat=
e and little technical details
that are coming into the game. Most of the p=
eople coming into theses
courses are not some J2EE or Struts gurus, which c=
an easily work with
any setup you offer in the course. They do some changes=
 now and then
and some others are taking care of the rest. Environmental de=
tails
shouldn't block them from seeing the TDD benefits. They may even thin=
k
later on that the course was all about the testing environment setup
or s=
omething really technical, but that shouldn't be the case!

I'm suggesting =
that TDD courses should stick with the simple examples
like spreadsheet. Th=
is way the actual TDD idea is visible all the time
and not the technical de=
tails.

One problem still is that most professional programmers don't want =
to
spend time with trivial things like spreadsheet applications, if they
do=
n't see some fundamental reasons for doing it. They want to see how
all hap=
pends in their build environment and with same size projects
that they deal=
 with.

This means that you have to sell the idea with concrete examples an=
d
experiences, before doing anything.

Teppo

On 5/20/05, Mike Clark <mike@=
clarkware.com> wrote:
> > How about Bill Wake's Spreadsheet idea <http://ww=
w.xp123.com/xplor/ 
> > xp0201/>?
> 
> Just to share what has worked well f=
or me...
> 
> In my TDD workshop we start with the Spreadsheet and then mov=
e on to  
> a shopping cart application, just to give a couple different  
=
> perspectives.  Some folks resonate more with one than another.
>
